projects.name: ZILLOW GROUP
projects.title: Zillow Group
projects.description: Zillow Group is the internet’s leading real estate marketplace. In addition to helping people browse house listings easily, Zillow Group provides real estate agents the opportunity to connect with potential homebuyers through their online real estate network, Zillow Premier Agent. This past summer I joined the Premier Agent UX team as a UX Engineer intern and contributed to several external-facing projects.

info-block-1.title: Skills
info-block-1.content: UI component + feature design, research + exploration, front-end dev, prototyping

sections.content: Zillow Premier Agent’s design system, Premier Agent Premier Agent Experience Language (PAXL), was founded to support the platform’s ongoing evolution. PAXL provides designers and engineers the foundation they need to build new product features quickly, while also delivering a consistent UX and brand experience to Premier Agent’s users.
This summer I had the opportunity to design and engineer a new component for PAXL’s UI library. More details on my design and development process coming soon!
I also was given the challenge to design a desktop newsfeed experience for Premier Agent. More details on this project coming soon!

projects.name: BUROW
projects.title: Burow
projects.description: What makes a place feel like a home? Burow is a desktop web application that helps people find the perfect neighbourhood to suit their needs. Focusing on livability metrics including price, walkability, and school rating, Burow makes it easy to discover the ideal location to complement your lifestyle.

info-block-1.title: Roles
info-block-1.content: Lead UX + visual designer, front-end engineer

info-block-1.title: Skills
info-block-1.content: Product design, design systems, web dev, user research, brand design

sections.content: When searching for a new place to live, popular real estate apps such as Zillow, Trulia, and Redfin first ask users for their desired location. Once selected, users can narrow down their results using metrics including price and number of bedrooms/bathrooms. Listings that catch the user’s interest can then be further researched in order to find their school rating, walkability, and more.

This user flow is intuitive for people who already have in mind a specific location they want to relocate to, however what if it were the opposite and you are trying to find the right neighbourhood for you?

To solve this problem, our team decided to reverse the user flow of standard real estate apps, allowing users to parse through neighbourhood data at a macro level. Our application sorts neighbourhoods within a city by the following criteria of price, walkability, and school rating.
The variability of these metrics can be drastic, even in close proximity neighbourhoods. Because of this, this user flow benefits users who are unfamiliar with the city they are moving to.

sections.content-1:
Existing Solution
Enter location → Receive listings → Use criteria to sort through listings
sections.content-2:
Proposed Solution
Enter city → Choose criteria → Receive neighbourhood results

sections.content: In order to empathize with our target users we interviewed participants about their home-searching experience. Based on the data collected, we drafted two storyboards with possible scenarios within the scope of our application.

sections.title: Competitive Analysis
sections.content: Zillow, Trulia, and Redfin utilize picturesque real estate photography, clean visual lines and crisp typefaces to establish a professional, trustworthy interface. This gives them a sense of credibility and safety, however at the cost of appearing apathetic and stock.

To help us explore different approaches to our solution we prototyped mobile and desktop variants of our application. Our solution needed to give users similar functionality to popular real estate apps, so we included familiar features such as price search criteria and an interactive map.

The major difference in our solution is the focus of livability criteria in the search algorithm. To reflect this, we included visualizations that bring attention to neighbourhoods that best fit the user’s selected criteria. This way areas that are a ‘best fit’ are easy to pinpoint amongst all of the search results available to the user.

Because our application does not provide listings or connect users with online real estate agencies, our team decided to switch out the professional look for a cozy, welcoming atmosphere. To produce a homey feel, we followed a theme of burrowing animals and leaned towards warm earth tones and typefaces with gentle curves.
"Burow - Dig around and find the neighbourhood that fits your needs!"

sections.title: Illustrations
sections.caption-content: Illustrations made by Emily. Concept created together.

sections.content: Redesigning a conventional user flow allowed me to test my understanding of the design process. Shifting the perspective of our target user from a micro-view to a macro-view resulted in an application that my team did not invision at first.

Despite this, we are satisfied with the solution our application provides. Through this project I also had another opportunity to advance my design and development skills, including branding, dynamic CSS styling, and working with React.js.

projects.name: DEXCOM
projects.title: Dexcom
projects.description: During my internship at Dexcom I worked as a UX Designer Intern under the IT Services team. The goal for my job was to improve user experience through internal and external projects. This included building upon user personas, mapping the user journey in order to obtain a Dexcom device, and designing a customer-companion mobile app.

sections.content: Dexcom is a rapidly expanding company and is one of the lead manufacturers in continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) technology. However, their current infrastructure will become unsustainable as the range of their customer market increases.

In order to support their customers throughout the sales process, starting from initial inquiries about products all the way to insurance processing and shipments, Dexcom needs to extend their methods of communicating and interacting with customers into a highly accessible, digital experience.

To better understand Dexcom’s customer base, my team analyzed and built upon customer personas created by the Dexcom marketing team. After reviewing customer interview videos and user segment documentation, we concluded the following:

sections.title: Dexcom customers...
sections.content:
• • want to have control over their diabetes, and not for their diabetes to have control over them
  • • are motivated and proactive in conquering their diabetes
  • • are generally tech savvy people

Once we defined who Dexcom’s potential customer market was, we documented the user journey customers take in order to receive a CGM device. By mapping out these steps, we were able to identify opportunities for Dexcom to step-in throughout the device acquisition process and alleviate customer anxiety.

sections.title: Insights
sections.content:
• • Corresponding through phone call can be inconvenient when customers live their own busy lives
  • • Customers are stressed about their status throughout the insurance verification process
  • • Communication between multiple parties (customer + insurance company + Dexcom) leaves users feeling confused about what actions to take next

Using the user research we gathered, my team and I designed and proposed the myDexcom companion app, a tool to increase customer communication, transparency, and retention. By providing an online portal where they can see the status of their insurance verification and be notified about the next steps in the process, customers are able to have a sense of security and convenience throughout the Dexcom customer UX process.

sections.caption-content: myDexcom app flow/feature whiteboard session. Completed as team.

sections.content: My experience at Dexcom was challenging but rewarding, as I had never worked in a fast-paced business environment before. Contributing to the improvement of real solutions and products allowed me to exercise my design abilities and creativity in a way that cannot be replicated through college curriculum.

As a young mind in a mature company setting, I thought I was able to bring fresh perspective and energy to the projects I was a part of. I am excited to see how I will continue to grow at my next workplace experience! If you want to learn more about what I worked on, I'd be happy to share! Let me know if you want to talk!

projects.name: BLYSS
projects.title: Blyss
projects.description: People are constantly connected to the world around them. Personal thoughts flood social media, creating a space that revolves around sharing, leaving little breathing room for privacy. Blyss is a mobile web application where people can chronicle their thoughts, reflect on their emotions, and gain insight on their personal lifestyle patterns.

info-block-1.title: Skills
info-block-1.content: Interaction design, front-end dev, UX research, brand design

sections.content: With the help of digital devices, we have an unprecedented ability to track our behaviors, habits, and thoughts. But turning data about ourselves and our communities into valuable insights is still remarkably difficult.
Our team’s objective was to explore ways to support monitoring, reflection, and behavior change by collecting, consuming, and sharing personally relevant information.

My team interviewed three participants about their daily routines and observed their behaviors throughout the course of the day. During observation we would periodically ask our participants to reflect on a situation or activity that occurred and ask relevant follow-up questions.

"I tend to jump from one thing to the next. Sometimes I feel like I don’t have time to sit down and enjoy myself."
- Research Participant

Based on the data we collected, my team discovered that our participants were so engrossed in their daily responsibilities that they often did not take time to relax nor incorporate self-care time into their schedules.
After analyzing our user research, we refined our results and pain points into the following prompts:

• • How might we help users gain insight about themselves emotionally and mentally?
      • How can we catalog a user’s feelings in a given day?
      • How might we remind users about the activities and content that make them happy?

In order to encourage positive thinking, our solution was an application that composes an anthology of moments and media for users to reflect on, ultimately boosting their mood. Users can make posts to a personal feed that include details of how they were feeling at a certain time and any accompanying media, such as a song, photo, or video.

Because the topic of our design brief is about inciting change from personal data, we decided to include an insights page where users can view breakdowns of their moods and receive suggestions on how to boost their well being. Suggestions can range from a funny video from the day before or reminders of positive moments that happened during the week.
To further understand our target users, my team drew storyboards with possible scenarios in which our app could be used.
Building off of our storyboards, we came up with personas that represent the various needs and problems our solution is aiming to resolve.
Our paper prototype focused on the user flow and interaction of creating and viewing posts. After testing we had our users score our application using usability heuristics.
Next, we created high-fidelity wireframes based on our paper prototype to visualize the flow of our application.

Our styling approach was inspired by social media apps, such as Instagram and Twitter, so we incorporated similar design standards. Some elements we emulated are a vertical scrolling chronological feed, a bottom-navigation bar, and an interface with generous white space and one accent color.

To develop our live prototype, we utilized tools including HTML, CSS, Javascript, and Node.js (Express + Handlebars). Our goal was to implement our core functions and ensure our app was responsive and fluid.

Because Blyss’s purpose is to provide insight and self-awareness to users, we conducted an A/B test on the curated content page. The results of our tests showed that page engagement was significantly higher when we gave users the option to view all of their posts by category of emotion. We changed the page’s design to reflect this as it allowed for more transparency and flexibility, which better aligned with our app’s objective.

This project was my first in-depth experience with the UX engineering process. From needfinding with user interviews to iterating on prototypes, I was able to participate in all stages of the design process.

I learned that designers should watch what users do, not say and that user feedback is the most valuable tool to utilize when designing. This is because a designer’s role is to create experiences not for themselves, but for the audience they are attempting to reach. In addition, I realized the importance soft skills, such as communication and trust, when working as a team.
